explanation:
- UtAssert_Compare_t (type/enum definition): The MISRA rule concerns whether the controlling expression (CompareType) is invariant. To decide this we must know the declared type (enum vs integer), its possible values/range, and whether any semantic guarantees (e.g., fixed-value macros, constant folding) apply. The full typedef/enum definition provides that.

- UtAssert_Compare_<...> (each enumerator listed): The switch selects on these specific constants. The exact enumerator values and whether additional/unknown values exist are required to determine whether the controlling expression can take different values at runtime or is effectively a compile-time constant (invariant). Having the enumerator definitions also shows whether the set is expanded via macros or conditional compilation.

- UtAssert_GenericIntegerCompare (caller function): This is the only call-site of UtAssert_GetOpText (per the call graph). To determine whether CompareType can be invariant at the point of the switch, we must inspect the caller to see how it computes/passes CompareType (e.g., literal constant, derived from runtime data, or preserved from a global). If the caller always passes a constant, the controlling expression in GetOpText would be invariant; if it computes CompareType at runtime, it is not invariant.
